question: leek and potato soup
option1: 45 grams butter    4  leeks chopped    350 grams potatoes diced    1 litre chicken stock    Instructions    In a saucepan, melt half the butter over low heat. Add the leeks and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 5 minutes. Add the potatoes and cook for 3 minutes.    Increase the heat to medium, pour in the stock and bring to boil. Reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook until the leeks and potatoes are tender, 35 to 40 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat and add the remaining butter in small pieces, stirring until it’s all incorporated.    Season with sea salt and pepper to taste. Transfer to a blender and puree until smooth. Serve in warm bowls.
option2: 45 grams butter    4  leeks chopped    350 grams potatoes diced    1 litre chicken stock    Instructions    In a saucepan, melt half the butter over low heat. Add the leeks and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 5 minutes. Add the potatoes and cook for 3 minutes.    Increase the heat to medium, pour in the stock and bring to boil. Reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook until the leeks and potatoes are tender, 35 to 40 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat and add the remaining butter in small pieces, stirring until it’s all incorporated.    Season with sea weed and pepper to taste. Transfer to a blender and puree until smooth. Serve in warm bowls.

question: How often should I water my apple tree?
option1: If the tree is one or two years old, give it a really deep watering twice a week, or less often if the rain is plentiful in your area. After a fruit tree is 3 + years old water only when the soil is dry to 8 inches or so. When the tree is just establishing itself, deep watering promotes deep roots and shallow watering promotes shallow roots, a liability for a tree.
option2: Apple trees don't need to be watered at all unless you live in a complete desert. Let mother nature take care of it.

question: How did Amazon get its name?
option1: An often reported story on how Amazon got its name is that Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, had at first suggested "cadaver" as it rhymes with Abracadabra. His lawyer thought it would be better to have an exotic name, so they chose Amazon as it begins with the letter A, thought to be an advantage when searching for companies or services.
option2: An often reported story on naming the company describes the founder, Jeff Bezos, telling his lawyer he wanted to call the company "cadabra", from abracadabra. When his lawyer thought he said "cadaver", Mr. Bezos decided Amazon was a better choice as it sounded exotic, and it started with A which may have been an advantage to customers finding the name near the top in a directory when searching for companies or services.
